text: Alchemy Calais Open Source Natural Language Processing
label: HH2

text: A proof of concept (PoC) was completed using open-source natural language processing technology to
label: BODY

text: parse resumes, job opening descriptions (OSOS database), and training opportunity descriptions (ETP
label: BODY

text: database)  and match, based on tagged metadata, an individual’s resume with potential job and training
label: BODY

text: opportunities.
label: BODY

text: This PoC proved to be successful with approximately 70-80% accuracy on matching. We believe by
label: BODY

text: cleaning the data we query against in our databases, and exploring alternative data repositories (using
label: BODY

text: information from web sites like Monster.com for job listings and exploring additional training providers),
label: BODY

text: we can get the accuracy percentage much higher. We’d also like to increase the robustness of the
label: BODY

text: application by adding mapping/geo-coding technology to allow for searching within a specified geographic
label: BODY

text: area. (For example, available opportunities within 20 miles of a specified zip code).
label: BODY

text: Current Status Report:   8/20/2010 Continued analysis of data sources to provide the most relevant
label: HH1

text: search results for training and job opportunities began. Both Alchemy & Calais open-source natural
label: BODY

text: language processing tools have been utilized at this point. Currently, our data sources to run against
label: BODY

text: these tools have been our own job listing and training provider databases. Currently, we are exploring an
label: BODY

text: external site to see if they offer a service that would allow us to search a broader list of job listings. Geo-
label: BODY

text: mapping technology is being explored to provide search results for training or employment opportunities
label: BODY

text: within a specific (e.g. 10, 25 or 50) mile radius from a specified zip code.
label: BODY

text: Contact Center Implementation
label: HH2

text: The New York State Department of Labor (NYSDOL) is a leader in providing integrated customer service
label: BODY

text: to jobseekers, workers and employers in the highly competitive workforce of the 21st century.  The
label: BODY

text: Department fulfills its mission through a wide variety of activities that revolve around the needs of
label: BODY

text: employers and workers.
label: BODY

text: The Department:
label: BODY

text: Administers the Unemployment Insurance Program, which provides temporary financial support
label: BODY

text: for those who have lost their jobs through no fault of their own.
label: BODY

text: Provides employment-related information and job search assistance services.
label: BODY

text: Provides training programs and retraining programs for workers displaced by technology change
label: BODY

text: or foreign competition.
label: BODY

text: Enforces regulations designed to minimize hazards in the workplace.
label: BODY

text: Works with the private sector to create job opportunities for the labor force and to meet employer
label: BODY

text: needs for qualified workers.
label: BODY

text: Enforces the State Labor Law to prevent the exploitation of workers, including minors and
label: BODY

text: immigrant workers.
label: BODY

text: Protects the safety of the public on ski tows, amusement rides and in places of public assembly.
label: BODY

text: Regulates the handling of asbestos to protect both workers and the general public.
label: BODY

text: Provide accurate and timely data on present and future economic trends affecting the people of
label: BODY

text: the state.
label: BODY

text: Works as a cooperating agency in the Federal/State labor market information statistical
label: BODY

text: programs.
label: BODY

text: Much of the information regarding the above services and regulations is not easily accessible to New
label: BODY

text: Yorkers.  To facilitate the provision of services and enforcement of regulations, the Department has
label: BODY

text: initiated an effort to create a centralized customer Contact Center.  The purpose of the new Contact
label: BODY

text: Center is to communicate information regarding program opportunities, instructions concerning NYSDOL
label: BODY

text: regulations, and general statistical information with regard to Department programs.
label: BODY

text: The communication channels that will be administered are:
label: BODY

text: Telephone
label: BODY

text: Email
label: BODY

text: Web Chat
label: BODY

text: Online Ticketing
label: BODY

text: COOP Emergency Notification System
label: HH2

text: The Continuity of Operations Plans (COOP) for the Department of Labor and its Divisions require an
label: BODY

text: emergency notification system that will allow the Department to promptly contact affected employees
label: BODY

text: during or outside of work hours in the event of an emergency which may impact on their job location. The
label: BODY

text: COOPs also require rosters of employees on emergency management teams with updated contact
label: BODY

text: information.
label: BODY

text: The Department currently does not have employee home contact information available electronically.
label: BODY

text: The Department plans to utilize NY-Alert system for emergency notification to its employees.  NY- Alert is
label: BODY

text: operated by the NYS Emergency Management Office (SEMO) at no cost to NYS agencies.  Under NY-
label: BODY

text: Alert, DOL personnel authorized by management will have the capability to send emergency messages to
label: BODY

text: employees which will be sent immediately and simultaneously to employees at each mode of contact that
label: BODY

text: employees have provided. An MOU between DOL and SEMO is in process.
label: BODY

text: This project will set up a process internally to collect the information and process any updates.  This
label: BODY

text: information can then be provided electronically to NY-Alert for integration into that system. The employee
label: BODY

text: data will only be utilized for sending emergency messages by DOL management and NY-Alert when that
label: BODY

text: system is operative.
label: BODY

text: plan to load it into the application.  The order form for NY-Alert is being reviewed and we will follow up

text: Customer Verification Service with Department of Motor Vehicles
label: HH2

text: Currently the Department of Labor (DOL) has an Oracle database stored procedures solution to query the
label: BODY

text: Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) when claimants apply for Unemployment Insurance benefits.  The
label: BODY

text: current solution was architected in 1997 when the DOL opened the Telephone Claim Centers.  The
label: BODY

text: solution is running on old technology (hardware and software) and we have experienced several
label: BODY

text: infrastructure failures at the DMV data center over the last 6 months.  These failures have caused
label: BODY

text: disruption to the DOL UI Claims taking operations.  DOL and DMV would like to refactor the current
label: BODY

text: solution to a web-services solution that can be reused with multiple applications and customers who may
label: BODY

text: need to consume/share this service.  DOL specifically is interested in modernizing the solution to improve
label: BODY

text: the performance and reliability of the technical interface to the DMV information thus improving the
label: BODY

text: workflow and processing of UI Claims that require DMV information for customer identity verification.
label: BODY

text: Current Status Report:  08/20/10 The MOU is in the mail.  It needs to be sent to DMV and then back to
label: BODY

text: DOL with the correct signatures.  The staging environment is having a firewall issue.  A request was

text: Data Sharing Assessment Project
label: HH2

text: The purpose of this project is to develop an analysis report for data sharing with other New York State
label: BODY

text: governmental entities, and to implement data sharing beginning with the New York State Insurance Fund.
label: BODY

text: The New York State Department of Labor (NYSDOL) is responsible for a variety of programs, including
label: BODY

text: Worker Protection, Unemployment Insurance, Employment Services, and Workforce Development.
label: BODY

text: Information from these programs is collected and maintained by various divisions in the department.
label: BODY

text: Many other governmental entities may find this information useful in that it could serve to decrease costs
label: BODY

text: and improve service by simplifying their operations and improving data quality.  NYSDOL information may
label: BODY

text: assist other governmental entities to verify the existence, location and status of employers, employees
label: BODY

text: and other program participants.   This information could be used to facilitate eligibility determination for
label: BODY

text: various other New York State programs, licenses and permits.

text: Disaster Recovery
label: HH2

text: There currently is no implemented Disaster Recovery (DR) plan or environment in place at New York
label: BODY

text: State Department of Labor (NYSDOL).  A DR plan has been created in December of 2008 for the
label: BODY

text: purposes of implementation but has not been executed.  Audits have been performed that have found
label: BODY

text: NYSDOL to be non-compliant with ensuring the appropriate back up of existing servers and applications.
label: BODY

text: There are two paths being followed on this project in parallel:
label: BODY

text: NYSDOL is working with the New York State Department of Labor Property Office (NYSDOL PO) to
label: BODY

text: determine the cost and terms associated with placing the DR site in the Glendale building #7 facility
label: BODY

text: located outside of Binghamton, NY.
label: BODY

text: One of the IBM Power6 595s purchased through the UNIX project will be used for the
label: BODY

text: Development/Testing/DR environment in BD-4.  It will initially be set up to prototype what the DR
label: BODY

text: environment will look like.  A decision will be made later in the process to see if the configured P6 595 will
label: BODY

text: be moved down to Glendale or if a new server will be purchased.
label: BODY

text: The goal is to set up the DR facility with the appropriate network, HVAC, Power, Data Circuits and
label: BODY

text: Network Security Devices; as well as procure the hardware (Servers, Voice Cards, PBX) to ensure the
label: BODY

text: continued operation of the UI Benefits Claims, SOA, and select Legacy systems.  The project will be
label: BODY

text: closed once these are in place.  Thereafter work will be tracked in the Keep projects within Technical
label: BODY

text: Services.

text: Document and Correspondence Management
label: HH2

text: For a very long time, DOL’s business has been very paper and image-based. As time progresses and we
label: BODY

text: move towards communicating with our customer via multiple channels (web, email, snail mail/paper) the
label: BODY

text: need to identify a solution for management of a complex document/correspondence environment
label: BODY

text: becomes very important.
label: BODY

text: Document and Correspondence Management is a project to identify all the different types of content that
label: BODY

text: DOL uses today (many produced from disparate products/sources). Additionally, we need to categorize
label: BODY

text: all content. These content categories would be would be: mass-printed letters (1-way communication to
label: BODY

text: DOL customer); one-off letters (printed one at a time; 1-way communication); forms (applications for
label: BODY

text: certain licenses or programs that we need to present both electronically & in paper formats; 1-way
label: BODY

text: communication from a customer to DOL); questionnaires (questionnaires sent to employers & claimants
label: BODY

text: during the adjudication process; 2-way communication between DOL and a customer).
label: BODY

text: One way communication to a DOL customer (one-off or mass printed) should use our existing xPression
label: BODY

text: solution, and the standards around how to do this must be adhered to. The overall
label: BODY

text: Document/Correspondence Standards will be part of this project. (although there are currently existing
label: BODY

text: usage documentation for xPression, which should be used and will be incorporated into this standard
label: BODY

text: when it is produced for this project)
label: BODY

text: For 2-way communication between DOL & a customer (forms & questionnaires), the solution will be
label: BODY

text: identified and implemented as part of this project.
label: BODY

text: EA Foundational Services
label: HH2

text: In a Service Oriented Architecture (SOA), small computer programs called services are orchestrated into
label: BODY

text: composite applications that provide many different functions to end users. These services can be
label: BODY

text: categorized many ways and provide many different types of capabilities. At Labor we often look at our
label: BODY

text: services in four basic layers.  The first layer is Foundational Services, which deals with things like
label: BODY

text: workflow, error-message-handling, logging, routing, caching, and notifications.  It is expected that New
label: BODY

text: York State’s SOA based modernization effort will be greatly accelerated so it is now essential that the
label: BODY

text: foundational services be completed based on industry and Labor specific standards, best practices and
label: BODY

text: patterns.
label: BODY

text: Four foundational services in particular will be addressed.   Workflow, GUI Framework, Correspondence
label: BODY

text: Management and Document Management will be the focus of this project, based on their criticality and
label: BODY

text: the amount of work remaining to complete them.
label: BODY

text: Tasks involved in this project would include:
label: BODY

text: Final design for each foundational service. The primary high level design documents have been
label: BODY

text: completed. The first goal of the project team will be to complete deeper level design so that the
label: BODY

text: development sprints may be initiated. This may require additional requirements gathering from
label: BODY

text: the CAD teams that will be consuming these services
label: BODY

text: Develop each foundational service. Development will be carried out in an agile, iterative fashion.
label: BODY

text: Sufficient design will have been conducted to develop each service, and the CAD teams will have
label: BODY

text: the opportunity to review deliverables regularly, and requirements and design will be adjusted as
label: BODY

text: needed.
label: BODY

text: Testing of each foundational service. Testing at the end of each delivery cycle will ensure that the
label: BODY

text: development teams are meeting the requirements of the Composite Application Development
label: BODY

text: (CAD) teams. Testing will include unit testing, to demonstrate that each module produces the
label: BODY

text: expected outputs. Integrated tests will make certain that each service behaves as expected when
label: BODY

text: interacting with all pieces of a composite application. Finally, performance testing will assess the
label: BODY

text: service’s capacity to perform at acceptable levels under the duress of high levels of concurrent
label: BODY

text: transactions.
label: BODY

text: Deployment. Once the testing of each foundational service is complete, the service will be
label: BODY

text: promoted to the Production environment.
label: BODY

text: ECM for Worker's Comp
label: HH2

text: This project will take existing documentation that is currently maintained in hard copy and store it
label: BODY

text: electronically within the ECM repository.   Users will be given the means to import new data as it arrives.
label: BODY

text: Users will use a web interface to access stored data.  Initial use will be limited to the personnel unit but
label: BODY

text: moving forward access could be afforded to authorized users for access to predefined  views; a claimant
label: BODY

text: to view their case file, for instance.   Additionally, this project will look to utilize the workflow capabilities of
label: BODY

text: ECM in an attempt to streamline the Workers Compensation process.
label: BODY

text: The implementation of this project will provide increased security of sensitive personnel documentation as
label: BODY

text: data will now be password protected.  Access will be limited to specific users with predefined rights.  In
label: BODY

text: addition, there is an expectation of improvement in both accuracy and expediency as the risk for human
label: BODY

text: error is greatly reduced.  Electronic files are far less susceptible to loss, damage or misplacement then
label: BODY

text: the current hard copy system.  ECM can alert users when a document has lingered longer than what is
label: BODY

text: considered acceptable thereby greatly reducing the chances for accidental oversights.  Finally,
label: BODY

text: implementation will significantly limit the amount of paper required to accommodate the unit’s tasks.
label: BODY

text: Effectively reducing paper, printer and toner costs as electronic versions of documentation are available
label: BODY

text: for use and reuse.
label: BODY

text: HR Personnel-LATS
label: HH2

text: The HR Personnel-LATS project is an effort to reengineer, develop and implement a modern Human
label: BODY

text: Resource/Personnel and Time and Attendance system for the NYS Department of Labor.  The new
label: BODY

text: system will function as a single integrated Human Resource Management (HRM) system (Personnel,
label: BODY

text: Time and Attendance).  It will interface directly with systems at the various control agencies so that
label: BODY

text: centralized data entry can be avoided.  The new system will provide a user interface that is easy to use
label: BODY

text: and understand.  It will offer built in capability for user defined ad hoc reports to enhance the
label: BODY

text: management capabilities offered by the system.  The new system will be well established and tested by
label: BODY

text: other agencies.  The current HR systems in use today are mainframe based systems that have been
label: BODY

text: expanded and enhanced many times over the years to address functionality issues as well as
label: BODY

text: requirements placed on us by the NYS Office of the State Comptroller, NYS Department of Civil Service,
label: BODY

text: and the NYS Division of the Budget. As a result of this steady stream of enhancements and new
label: BODY

text: requirements, these systems are in need of an overhaul.  The resulting system should meet all the needs
label: BODY

text: of the control agencies as well as provide the NYS Department of Labor with a more cohesive and user
label: BODY

text: friendly system for the staff in the Administrative Finance Bureau and Human Resources, as well as the
label: BODY

text: employees throughout the agency that use these systems routinely.
label: BODY

text: The first phase of this project is to do data gathering regarding the current HRM systems.  The NYS
label: BODY

text: Department of Labor is identifying the connection points between its legacy HRM systems and other
label: BODY

text: applications.  A description of the data that is sent into the HRM system and what is retrieved is being
label: BODY

text: documented to be used to complete the Fit-Gap with an inter-agency hosted "commercial off the shelf"
label: BODY

text: solution.

text: Implement Integrated AIX TWS with zOS TWS
label: HH2

text: Implement an integrated Tivoli Workload Scheduling (TWS) system that will allow DOL to manage and
label: BODY

text: coordinate open system server based batch jobs from a centralized location.  As data is migrated from
label: BODY

text: mainframe based solutions (software and data structures) to server (AIX, MS Windows and other) based
label: BODY

text: solutions, it is increasingly import to manage the coordination of batch executed server processes (batch
label: BODY

text: jobs) in a coordinated fashion.  It is also important that we be able to setup and execute a sequence of
label: BODY

text: defined processes with both regular (daily, weekly, monthly) and irregular frequency (on demand) and
label: BODY

text: also to stop the execution of processes in the event of batch failures and to send error notification for
label: BODY

text: immediate action and/or result reporting and automated notifications . These features of batch scheduling
label: BODY

text: and management are well established on the z/OS TWS system and we need to implement a similar
label: BODY

text: scheduler for open systems based processes.  A proposed solution would be one that leveraged the z/OS
label: BODY

text: TWS system to manage the sequencing and coordination of the server jobs (since we already have an
label: BODY

text: established Production Control environment and relationship with OFT for support).  To do this we believe
label: BODY

text: we need an AIX based TWS node implemented to integrate the z/OS TWS environment.

text: Telephone Call Center Collaboration Assessment
label: HH2

text: The purpose of this project is to investigate opportunities for call center collaboration with other New York
label: BODY

text: State governmental entities and to implement call center collaboration beginning with the New York State
label: BODY

text: Insurance Fund. The New York State Department of Labor (NYSDOL) has an established and mature call
label: BODY

text: center operation with resources that could possibly be shared at an overall savings to the State.  The
label: BODY

text: NYSDOL telephony infrastructure currently supports over 300 call center agents in three agency
label: BODY

text: locations; Albany, NY, Glendale, NY, and Troy, NY.  NYSDOL’s potentially sharable assets include:
label: BODY

text: Call Center Infrastructure – Telephony hardware and software, i.e., trunks, servers, switches,
label: BODY

text: Computer Telephony Integration (CTI), Interactive Voice Response, (IVR), outbound dialing, etc.,
label: BODY

text: as well as applications to be installed by the end of State Fiscal Year 2009-2010 which will
label: BODY

text: manage call prioritization, on-hold scheduled call back, and web chat.
label: BODY

text: Call Center Agent Human Resources – trained staff are available to accept and direct calls, and
label: BODY

text: perform real-time inquires and updates on behalf of callers.
label: BODY

text: Any or all of the above assets have the potential to be shared.  NYSDOL might collaborate with another
label: BODY

text: governmental entity by sharing Call Center Agents.  Voice ports, CTI, IVR, outbound dialing, on-hold
label: BODY

text: scheduled call back or web chat might be shared individually or in any combination.

text: Transfer of NYS Job Bank from AJE to JobCentral NLX
label: HH2

text: Replace the current NYS Job Exchange hosted by AJE to a new site to be hosted by JobCentral National
label: BODY

text: Labor Exchange (NLX).  We have had escalating problems with AJE due to ongoing changes being made
label: BODY

text: to make the site self-supporting and/or profitable. These changes include the charging of fees for service
label: BODY

text: to both job seekers and employers, advertising, move of the customer support services to India, and
label: BODY

text: expanding partnerships with other fee-charging job sites allowing more listings that are suspect. There is
label: BODY

text: little to no notice of significant changes being made to the site and insufficient firewall protections
label: BODY

text: between the NYS hosted site and the national public site. In addition, AJE has taken the position that they
label: BODY

text: 'own' the employer job order data from employer registered with the NYS site. This is in conflict with the
label: BODY

text: state's understanding when the hosting arrangement was made. Note that New Jersey has already
label: BODY

text: severed their relation with AJE for this reason and we understand that Kentucky is moving in that
label: BODY

text: direction as well. At the same time we have seen major improvements to the JobCentral NLX site. Since
label: BODY

text: inception the JobCentral site has grown significantly and now has the participation of as many more
label: BODY

text: states than AJB had prior to termination (while AJE has comparatively few states participating at this
label: BODY

text: point). Through the JobCentral association with NASWA, the needs of the public labor exchange and the
label: BODY

text: State's participation on the JobCentral operations committee have direct input into changes and
label: BODY

text: enhancements made to the site. JobCentral limits the sources of jobs coming into the NLX, thus providing
label: BODY

text: the states with more protection against the types of problems seen with AJE. In addition, JobCentral staff
label: BODY

text: is much more responsive to requests from states and offer many other advantages thru their association
label: BODY

text: with NASWA and their employer membership.  This change has been approved by executive level staff.
label: BODY

text: In addition, Counsel's office has agreed that this change is within the terms of the current contracts that
label: BODY

text: NYSDOL has with both Navisite/AJE and
label: BODY

text: DEA/JobCentral NLX, so no additional procurement process steps are needed.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: request based on an audit determination. This project will also provide NYSDOL users with electronic
label: BODY

text: UI Audit and Investigation Case Management System
label: HH2

text: The purpose of this project is to re-design the Case Management System (CMS) currently used by UI Tax
label: BODY

text: Enforcement Staff.  The project includes automating the selection of audits and investigations, manual
label: BODY

text: requests for investigations, routing the assignments to the correct enforcement staff, transferring
label: BODY

text: assignments between offices and staff, facilitate the scheduling of field staff appointments, allowing
label: BODY

text: enforcement supervisors to manage assignments, and providing workflow for supervisory and Quality
label: BODY

text: Assurance review of completed assignments.
label: BODY

text: The Case Management System is a mainframe based system that contains cases that have been
label: BODY

text: automatically selected for follow-up work enforcement work.  There are a number of reasons why a case
label: BODY

text: might be selected.  Examples are for Failure to File (FTF) a wage report, or for a delinquent wage report.
label: BODY

text: Not all cases are selected automatically.  Some are manually generated, such as Miscellaneous cases
label: BODY

text: and Liability cases, and must be keyed in by the Central Assignment and Collection unit (CACS) staff.
label: BODY

text: The follow up work in the Case Management System might be work performed in the Central Assignment
label: BODY

text: and Collection unit, (a UI Tax Enforcement unit) or an assignment to be handled in the field by UI Tax
label: BODY

text: Services.    The Case Management System was not completed when it was originally built.  It does not
label: BODY

text: include Benefit Claims Investigations and Collection Assignments.  Bank Levies are also not in the Case
label: BODY

text: Management System.  Bank Levies are handled external to CMS in a Microsoft Access Bank Levy
label: BODY

text: application.   The Bank Levy System records pertinent information about employers bank accounts,
label: BODY

text: warrants placed against employers, and levies sent to banks to collect against employers’ accounts, and
label: BODY

text: the status of those levies.
label: BODY

text: This project will also develop a portable computer system to facilitate field work done by UI Tax Auditors
label: BODY

text: and Tax Compliance Agents, and replace the current Tax Services Database Management System
label: BODY

text: (TSDBMS).  This includes data gathering via keyboard input and file import, calculations of amounts due,
label: BODY

text: estimation of amounts due, collection of amounts due, penalty and interest calculations, report
label: BODY

text: generation, data upload and download with primary UI system, forms generation, daily activities reporting,
label: BODY

text: electronic signature capture, and calendar synchronization.
label: BODY

text: The current Tax Services Database Management System was developed using Microsoft Access.  It is
label: BODY

text: deployed on laptops that UI Tax Auditors and Tax Compliance Agents bring into the field to record the
label: BODY

text: results of their assignments.  The UI Tax Auditors and Tax Compliance Agents receive their assignments
label: BODY

text: as paper printouts sent from the Central Assignment and Collection Services unit (CACS).  The data
label: BODY

text: enter the assignment information into TSDBMS.  Manual input of employer information wastes Field Staff
label: BODY

text: and employer time, and is subject to keying errors.
label: BODY

text: The results of each field assignment are printed.  Investigation assignments are mailed to the District
label: BODY

text: Supervisor, who reviews each assignment.  Afterward, the District Supervisor sends the reviewed
label: BODY

text: assignment paperwork to the central office for Quality Assurance unit review.  Audit assignments are sent
label: BODY

text: directly to the CACS.  The need to print and mail completed assignment paperwork wastes paper, time,
label: BODY

text: and postage.  Some information is uploaded from the field staffs’ TSDBMS to a server, where it is
label: BODY

text: downloaded into to the Microsoft Access based system called the Assignment Register.  The Assignment
label: BODY

text: Register maintains a history of field assignments and is used for Federal and NYS reporting.
label: BODY

text: UI Benefit Adjudication
label: HH2

text: This project will redesign processes related to the adjudication of non-monetary issues.  At the present
label: BODY

text: time, claim issues are identified automatically based upon information supplied when the claimant files
label: BODY

text: the claim through the Internet or the phone, once the claimant has completed the claim, the information is
label: BODY

text: submitted to one of the Mainframe applications called Unemployment Benefits Wage Reporting system
label: BODY

text: (UBWR).  Every morning the Telephone Claims Centers (TCCs) download claims with issues from the
label: BODY

text: UBWR system into a Microsoft Access system which is referred to as Case Management.  Once the
label: BODY

text: UBWR data is in Case Management, the adjudication units sort and query the information based on their
label: BODY

text: assignment needs.  For example, the Adjudication Units will sort the Case Management data by the last 4
label: BODY

text: digits of the Social Security Number and assign them to adjudicators within specific ranges (e.g., from
label: BODY

text: 0000 to 1054).  Adjudications Units will also sort the Case Management data into Spanish claims (Local
label: BODY

text: Office 809, 839, 889), or all the claims with a given effective date.
label: BODY

text: Assignments are given to adjudicators via the Cases Management System.  The adjudicators accept
label: BODY

text: cases, and annotate results in the Microsoft Access Case Management System.  To adjudicate claims
label: BODY

text: issues, adjudicators frequently contact claimants and employers to gather information needed to make
label: BODY

text: eligibility determinations. They may call either party, or send forms or questionnaires to obtain
label: BODY

text: information.  When adjudicators take statements via telephone, they transcribe the statement into forms
label: BODY

text: that exist in the Letter Generator System.  Those forms are automatically imaged and saved with the
label: BODY

text: claimant’s imaged file.  When adjudicators request written information, they later look for written
label: BODY

text: responses from claimants by manually searching the File Access Facility (FAF), to see if correspondence
label: BODY

text: or questionnaires were returned and imaged.  Adjudicators view UBWR mainframe inquiry screens, and
label: BODY

text: run COGNOS reports to research information that was reported when claimants filed their Original Claim.
label: BODY

text: This is done to compare it to statements made to the adjudicators.  In instances where there are
label: BODY

text: discrepancies, the adjudicators send the COGNOS reports to be imaged by UI Division Central Support
label: BODY

text: to be added to the claimants image file.
label: BODY

text: The current automated method of supporting claims adjudication is inefficient.  Much time is lost in
label: BODY

text: adjudicating claims, and information is not fully captured or used to automatically drive the process.
label: BODY

text: Information is stored in disparate nonintegrated systems, and is frequently captured only in image form,
label: BODY

text: rather than as data.  Information needed by adjudicators is spread across the FAF system, UBWR
label: BODY

text: system, Case Management System, and Voice/Web system (accessed via COGNOS).  Many
label: BODY

text: applications in use are no longer supported.
label: BODY

text: UI Benefit Ledger Replacement
label: HH2

text: This project will replace the current Claimant Benefit Ledger with a newer, and easier to use ledger.  The
label: BODY

text: current ledger was written several decades ago and is no longer able to efficiently handle today’s UI
label: BODY

text: Benefits business. Programming maintenance is risky because code has been pieced together over many
label: BODY

text: years. Also, a great deal of information currently stored on the ledger is not financial information. This
label: BODY

text: project will separate information currently stored on the claimant ledger into the financial transaction
label: BODY

text: information and the employer charging information. Because this data is interrelated, a relationship must
label: BODY

text: be created to provide the ability to view employer charges associated with a payment and view payments
label: BODY

text: associated with an employer’s charges.
label: BODY

text: Currently, few adjustments to the ledger are automated. Most require UI staff to calculate the adjustment
label: BODY

text: amounts and enter the transactions into a batch update process. There are limited edits on the entries;
label: BODY

text: therefore, transactions are frequently rejected during the batch run because the transactions do not
label: BODY

text: balance.  Adjustment transactions will be calculated and posted to the ledger automatically in as many
label: BODY

text: cases as possible.  UI staff will be able to post transactions on-line that cannot be posted automatically.
label: BODY

text: Other processes that use the ledger information may require interface capabilities, such as the
label: BODY

text: overpayment system, jump keys that access the ledger, and the master file build. In addition, OTDA also
label: BODY

text: accesses this information.
label: BODY

text: UI Benefits Certification
label: HH2

text: This project is intended to re-design of all of the processes associated with weekly certification for regular
label: BODY

text: UI benefits. It also includes the re-design of all of the processes associated with weekly certification for UI
label: BODY

text: special programs including shared work, TRA, DUA and SEP.  This project will leverage the existing voice
label: BODY

text: web platform to implement the enhancements designed by UISIM for the processes associated with UI
label: BODY

text: weekly certifications. It includes modifying the existing platform to allow self-service web certifications for
label: BODY

text: shared work claimants/employers, TRA claimants, SEP claimants and DUA claimants currently accepted
label: BODY

text: in paper form only. This project will add the necessary front end screens/rules/logic and backend logic to
label: BODY

text: process certifications on-line for all of the special programs claimants. The special programs certification
label: BODY

text: functionality includes an on-line application for shared work employers to submit weekly certifications on
label: BODY

text: behalf of their shared work employees. The design allows the employer to complete one certification for
label: BODY

text: all of the employees at once. Today, the shared work employer is required to complete the bottom portion
label: BODY

text: the paper certification separately for each employee.  It also includes the enhancements to the
label: BODY

text: certification application to collect last employer information for additional claims.
label: BODY

text: This project will also upgrade the weekly certification application on the voice web platform to allow for
label: BODY

text: missed certification weeks on the web. Currently, when a claimant forgets to certify for a given week and
label: BODY

text: then calls to certify the next week they need to speak with a TCC representative to submit the certification
label: BODY

text: for the missed week. Once the skip week functionality is implemented, the system will accept the
label: BODY

text: certification for the missed (skip) week without human intervention.

text: UI Employer Tax Ledger Replacement
label: HH2

text: This project will replace the current employer ledger with a newer, and easier to use ledger.  The current
label: BODY

text: ledger was written several decades ago and is no longer able to efficiently handle today’s UI tax
label: BODY

text: business.  Currently the ledger is not capable of accounting for two penalty liabilities.  These liabilities
label: BODY

text: must be maintained on a separate Penalty System.  Maintenance of employer accounts is largely a
label: BODY

text: manual process that requires extensive training for staff to become productive in the required tasks.
label: BODY

text: Currently, few adjustments to the ledger are automated. This project would also separate the financial
label: BODY

text: information from that other non-financial information that is stored in the same file structure.
label: BODY

text: The scope of this project will include the ability to process remittance adjustments, post returns,
label: BODY

text: payments, and voluntary payments to an Employer Account, create employer payments online, perform
label: BODY

text: daily remittance balancing, and interface with NYS Department of Taxation and Finance late filer
label: BODY

text: information and Failure to file data.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: considered delinquent at the given point in time that the query is executed, produce a daily pre-
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: UI Virtual Call Queuing Callback Manager Project
label: HH2

text: The Unemployment Insurance Division (UID) has moved from a local office model for claims intake, to a
label: BODY

text: self-service model.  As such, the primary means of receiving Unemployment Insurance claims is through
label: BODY

text: the Internet and through Interactive Voice Response (IVR).  Many claims that are submitted through the
label: BODY

text: IVR are incomplete. Claimants complete their applications by calling the Department of Labor and
label: BODY

text: verbally completing the application with the help of a Telephone Call Center (TCC) Agent. TCC Agents
label: BODY

text: input the remaining claim information into the Unemployment Insurance computer system as they speak
label: BODY

text: with the claimants.  There are two TCCs in the Department of Labor.  One is in Glendale, NY and the
label: BODY

text: other is in Troy, NY. The two call centers are in a Virtual Call Center (VCC) configuration. There are
label: BODY

text: approximately 250 total TCC Agents.  Calls are routed to one of the two centers where the application is
label: BODY

text: completed with the assistance of an Agent.  Many requests for information and claim status are also
label: BODY

text: received in the TCCs.
label: BODY

text: The volume of calls received in the Telephone Call Centers varies.  Monday sees the highest volume.
label: BODY

text: Mass layoffs and poor economic conditions also create a high volume of calls to the TCCs.  During those
label: BODY

text: peak volume periods, claimants may wait an excessive amount of time before connecting to an Agent.
label: BODY

text: This causes unnecessary 800 line costs and disgruntled claimants due to perceived poor customer
label: BODY

text: service.
label: BODY

text: The Unemployment Insurance Division has investigated Virtual Call Queuing Management software to
label: BODY

text: alleviate issues created by variable peaks in TCC call volumes.  Virtual Call Queuing Management
label: BODY

text: software is capable of allowing a claimant to disconnect and yet maintain their place in the incoming call
label: BODY

text: queue.  When an Agent becomes available, the system calls the claimant and makes the connection to
label: BODY

text: the Agent.  Software that has been investigated thus far also has the option of allowing claimants to
label: BODY

text: schedule a call back at a date and time that is convenient for the claimant.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of this project is to:  Develop a set of business and technical requirements needed to
label: BODY

text: determine the hardware, software and associated cost estimates for a Virtual Call Queuing Management
label: BODY

text: system for the Unemployment Insurance Division's Telephone Call Centers.
label: BODY

text: Procure software and hardware necessary for implementing a Virtual Call Queuing Management system
label: BODY

text: for the Unemployment Insurance Division.
label: BODY

text: Install, configure and test Virtual Call Queuing Management products.
label: BODY

text: Implement the Virtual Call Queuing Management system by training the UI Division administrators and
label: BODY

text: staff, preparing for ongoing Planning and Technology support, and transitioning the products into the
label: BODY

text: production environment.
label: BODY

text: call queuing software.  Several options were presented to improve performance.  No decision has been
label: BODY

text: made yet on what will be the next step.   A design meeting was held to review in more detail the steps
label: BODY

text: involved in the software upgrade part of this project.  There are several outstanding items that more
label: BODY

text: information is needed on but so far we have not identified any major issues.  We have decided that the
label: BODY

text: vendors can have VPN access to the servers for loading the software and doing the configuration and
label: BODY

text: custom coding work.   The paper work to enable this to happen is quickly going through the system.  Port
label: BODY

text: assignment and network firewall requirements for the various servers are being finalized.  Next week we
label: BODY

text: will provide the vendor a test of the current system so that they can see how the screen pops and agent
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY
